unnormalised: ## The Day My Percentage Didn't Define Me
normalised: ## The Day My Percentage Didn't Define Me

unnormalised: It's funny how one number can feel like it holds the weight of the world. I remember the day my Class 10th results came out like it was yesterday. It was a sweltering May afternoon in Delhi, the kind where the heat shimmers off the pavement and everything feels sluggish. My parents had preponed their office timings just to be home when the results were announced online at 2 PM. The whole atmosphere was charged.
normalised: It's funny how one number can feel like it holds the weight of the world. I remember the day my Class tenth results came out like it was yesterday. It was a sweltering May afternoon in Delhi, the kind where the heat shimmers off the pavement and everything feels sluggish. My parents had preponed their office timings just to be home when the results were announced online at two P-M. The whole atmosphere was charged.

unnormalised: My roll no. was 1234567. I refreshed the website countless times. Finally, there it was: my name, "Priya Sharma," staring back at me, followed by a series of numbers that would supposedly dictate my future. I scored 88%. Not bad, objectively speaking. Many of my friends were thrilled with similar or even lower scores. But I wasn't.
normalised: My roll number was one million two hundred and thirty four thousand five hundred and sixty seven. I refreshed the website countless times. Finally, there it was: my name, "Priya Sharma," staring back at me, followed by a series of numbers that would supposedly dictate my future. I scored eighty eight percent. Not bad, objectively speaking. Many of my friends were thrilled with similar or even lower scores. But I wasn't.

unnormalised: See, my elder brother, Rohan, had gotten 96% in his Class 10th. My parents, bless their hearts, hadn't meant to create a competition, but the unspoken comparison hung heavy in the air. Suddenly, my 88% felt… inadequate. I saw their initial reactions; a flicker of something that wasn't quite disappointment, but close enough. The celebratory laddoos seemed less sweet, the congratulations from relatives less genuine.
normalised: See, my elder brother, Rohan, had gotten ninety six percent in his Class tenth. My parents, bless their hearts, hadn't meant to create a competition, but the unspoken comparison hung heavy in the air. Suddenly, my eighty eight percent felt… inadequate. I saw their initial reactions; a flicker of something that wasn't quite disappointment, but close enough. The celebratory laddoos seemed less sweet, the congratulations from relatives less genuine.

unnormalised: For a few days, I was in a funk. I felt like I'd let everyone down, especially myself. I was convinced that 88% meant I wouldn't get into a good science stream in a decent school. The cut-offs, I’d heard, were soaring, some as high as 92%. My dreams of becoming an engineer, of getting into IIT, suddenly seemed distant, almost impossible.
normalised: For a few days, I was in a funk. I felt like I'd let everyone down, especially myself. I was convinced that eighty eight percent meant I wouldn't get into a good science stream in a decent school. The cut-offs, I’d heard, were soaring, some as high as ninety two percent. My dreams of becoming an engineer, of getting into I-I-T, suddenly seemed distant, almost impossible.

unnormalised: Then, something shifted. Maybe it was a pep talk from my Dad, maybe it was the sight of my friends celebrating their achievements, regardless of their percentage. Whatever it was, I realised that this one number didn't define me. It didn't erase my hard work, my late-night study sessions, the sacrifices I'd made. It was just a number.
normalised: Then, something shifted. Maybe it was a pep talk from my Dad, maybe it was the sight of my friends celebrating their achievements, regardless of their percentage. Whatever it was, I realised that this one number didn't define me. It didn't erase my hard work, my late-night study sessions, the sacrifices I'd made. It was just a number.

unnormalised: I ended up getting into my preferred school with a good science stream. I worked hard, focused on understanding the concepts rather than just memorizing for marks, and eventually scored well in my Class 12th with 91%. More importantly, I learned that academic results, while important, are not the only measure of success or potential.
normalised: I ended up getting into my preferred school with a good science stream. I worked hard, focused on understanding the concepts rather than just memorizing for marks, and eventually scored well in my Class twelfth with ninety one percent. More importantly, I learned that academic results, while important, are not the only measure of success or potential.

unnormalised: Years later, as I navigate my career, that lesson has stayed with me. I often think about that 88% and smile. It was a valuable lesson in resilience, self-worth, and the understanding that life is so much more than just a scorecard. It taught me that true success lies not in the numbers, but in the journey, the effort, and the person you become along the way. And honestly, the percentage you get in Class 10th is something you probably won't even remember after 10 years, unless you are writing a blog post about it.
normalised: Years later, as I navigate my career, that lesson has stayed with me. I often think about that eighty eight percent and smile. It was a valuable lesson in resilience, self-worth, and the understanding that life is so much more than just a scorecard. It taught me that true success lies not in the numbers, but in the journey, the effort, and the person you become along the way. And honestly, the percentage you get in Class tenth is something you probably won't even remember after ten years, unless you are writing a blog post about it.
